docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I can understand and empathize with women who are H.I.V. positive and want to have children, but in ''Women Now Look Beyond H.I.V., to Children and Grandchildren'' (Aug. 7), the needs of the children weren't even alluded to. It seems that unless a substantial prolongation of the mother's life is assured so the child will not be without her at an early age, a doctor's intervention is unethical.
docs.abstract: Ina Bomze letter questions wisdom of HIV positive women having children (Aug 7 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: While American researchers wait for politicians to issue rules on research involving human embryos, scientists in Britain are working under a less restrictive and more predictable system that allows many forms of research on embryonic stem cells and cloning. For a decade, researchers in Britain have been allowed to create human embryos for research purposes, an idea that was proposed in 1994 by a National Institutes of Health committee, specifically rejected by President Bill Clinton, and widely condemned in the United States when a clinic in Virginia announced last month that it had created scores of embryos expressly for research.

headline.main: STEM CELL STUDIES ADVANCE IN BRITAIN

docs.abstract: British scientists are working under less restrictive and more predictable system that allows many forms of research on embryonic stem cells, while American counterparts still await laws governing research involving human embryos; have been allowed for decade to create human embryos for research purposes, and to perform experiments in therapeutic cloning, to generate healthy replacements for diseased tissues from embryonic cells derived from patient's own mature cells; less restrictive approach attributed to less intense lobbying from abortion foes, longer track record of research in area, earlier start in public debate and generally respected regulatory authority; creation of human embryos for research purposes, proposed in 1994 by National Institutes of Health, was specifically rejected by Pres Bill Clinton and widely condemned across US when Virginia clinic disclosed it had created scores of embryos expressly for research; diagrams (M)
docs.snippet: While American researchers wait for politicians to issue rules on research involving human embryos, scientists in Britain are working under a less restrictive and more predictable system that allows many forms of research on embryonic stem cells and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents who have experienced the joy of bringing a healthy child into the world can hardly imagine the pain of losing a baby, even one not close to being born. I have a friend who suffered three miscarriages, another whose baby died in utero when she was eight months pregnant and a third whose baby was alive at the start of labor but was stillborn. The pain that accompanies such losses is shared by those who feel compelled to terminate wanted pregnancies after learning through amniocentesis that the fetus is seriously abnormal.

headline.main: After Ending Pregnancy, Ripples of Pain

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on pain of losing baby through miscarriage; says pain that accompanies such loss is shared by those who feel compelled to terminate wanted pregnancy after learning through amniocentesis that fetus is seriously abnormal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Berlin Wall Is a Memory; A Cultural Divide Remains Almost 12 years after Germans celebrated the reopening between east and west and attacked the hated Berlin Wall with sledgehammers, a reunified Berlin today will commemorate the 40th anniversary of the wall's construction. While there are few remnants of the wall, Germans still routinely talk about the ''wall in the mind'' to describe the social and cultural differences that continue to divide easterners and westerners. A1 More Mideast Violence The struggle over shuttered Palestinian offices in Jerusalem intensified after a Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in a group of Israelis at a cafe outside the northern Israel city of Haifa, wounding about 15 people, none gravely, and an 8-year-old girl was shot in the head and killed during exchanges of gunfire in the West Bank. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: The single women of ''Sex and the City'' are a bit older than they were four summers ago when their revealing discussions of the sex lives of contemporary New Yorkers became the talk of television. They are also sadder, lonelier and more desperate as they confront a range of unhappy circumstances, including unwanted pregnancy, cancer and a seemingly never-ending litany of unfulfilling relationships.

headline.main: On Television; Serious Tone Adds to Success of 'Sex and the City'

docs.abstract: HOB's Sex and the City wraps up its fourth summer run with ratings up 35 percent from last year; Sarah Jessica Parker, star and co-executive producer, says growth of audience may be due to the more serious issues addressed by show this season, including unwanted pregnancy, cancer and infertility; Chris Albrecht, HBO president, foresees no imminent closing episode for show; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a great deal of magic for a child in understanding his or her place in the rhythms of the generations. Did the world exist before I got here? What did it look like? Was my mother ever a child? What did she do before I was born? At the start of MY BABY (Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16; ages 3 to 8), a slight and enchanting book written and illustrated by Jeanette Winter, a child in Mali learns from her mother how to make the traditional handmade mud-dyed cloth called bogolan. Nakunte Diarra, a real woman, as an author's note tells us, becomes a celebrated bogolan painter, and the book follows her through her marriage, wearing a bogolan painted by her mother, to her pregnancy, when she starts making one for her own baby. The steps of the cloth painting are described in detail. Nakunte chooses the whitest cloth in the marketplace and then makes mud ''black as a starless night.'' She proceeds to draw with her painting stick, explaining to the child in her womb. ''Listen, my baby, do you hear the drums that call?'' she asks, drawing a border of drums. ''Mmmmmmmm, the calabash flower smells so sweet. Can you smell the sweetness, my baby?'' she says, as flowers appear on the intricate bogolan. When the rains come, the cloth is ready, and the baby comes as well.
docs.abstract: Jeanne B Pinder reviews book My Baby by Jeanette Winter; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: British immigration officers screening travelers at Prague's international airport will be withdrawn on Thursday, Czech and British officials said today, after politicians and human rights groups accused them of racial bias by deliberately preventing Czech Gypsies from traveling to Britain. British diplomats said the three-week-old controls were ended because they had been successful in virtually halting a flood of Czech asylum seekers, nearly all of whom were Gypsies. The diplomats denied the charges of racial bias, and said they reserved the right to reimpose the controls at any time.

headline.main: After Protest, British Halt Screening of Travelers in Prague

docs.abstract: Britain to withdraw its immigration officers screening travelers at Prague airport after politicians and human rights groups charge they deliberately barred Czech Gypsies from traveling to Britain; holds three-week-old controls are being ended because they have successfully halted flood of Czech asylum seekers, almost all of whom were Gypsies; denies racial bias and reserves right to reimpose controls (M)
